did.head: DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY
did.physdesc: Correspondence, Diaries, Manuscripts, Photographs, Printed Materials, Publications, Reports, Research Materials
did.repository: Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library
did.abstract: Alphabetical correspondence, files relating to European trips, manuscripts, slides, and photographs relating to his research on siting vineyards, grapevine physiology, vineyard mechanization and management, mineral nutrition, rootstocks, and canopy microclimates. Also research pertaining to an unfinished book.

bioghist.head: BIOGRAPHICAL NOTE
bioghist.p: Professor of Viticulture, New York State Agricultural Experiment Station, Geneva.

Nelson Shaulis graduated with a B.S. in horticulture and an M.S. in agronomy from Pennsylvania State University. He received his Ph.D. from Cornell in 1941. He served as a soil conservationist with the USDA Soil Conservation Service from 1938 to 1944, while he was also an instructor and assistant professor of pomology at Penn State. In 1944, he was appointed assistant professor of pomology at Cornell, and became professor of pomology and viticulture from 1948 to 1967. He retired as professor of viticulture in 1978. His major contributions to the grape industry included a training system for grapes called the Geneva Double Curtain (GDC), which he initiated at the Experiment Station in 1960 and with growers in 1964. He also helped to develop the mechanical grape harvester. Shaulis was named a fellow of the American Society of Horticultural Science in 1972 and in 1997 was the recipient of the Merit Award given by the American Society for Enology and Viticulture (ASEV), the highest award of the society. He also received Merit Awards from the Society of Wine Educators, the American Wine Society, the New York State Wine and Grape Foundation, and the National Grape Cooperative.

scopecontent.head: COLLECTION DESCRIPTION
scopecontent.p: Alphabetical correspondence, files relating to European trips, manuscripts, slides, and photographs relating to his research on siting vineyards, grapevine physiology, vineyard mechanization and management, mineral nutrition, rootstocks, and canopy microclimates. Also research pertaining to an unfinished book.

controlaccess.head: Names:
controlaccess.corpname: New York State Agricultural Experiment Station.

descgrp.head: INFORMATION FOR USERS

prefercite.head: Cite As:
prefercite.p: Nelson J. Shaulis papers, #22-2-3140. Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library.

descgrp.p: Pom and PM followed by a number indicate 5.5” x 7.75” negative envelopes with photos of plants, fields, or charts/tables. Only a very few also have slides or negatives enclosed.
Portions of unpublished book are located in Boxes 26, and in various folders throughout the collection which include "book" in the title, non-exclusively.
Colored, but blank post-it notes were attached so some boxes of slides but no key available. These notes were left attached to the first section heading card in the box.

relatedmaterial.head: RELATED MATERIALS
relatedmaterial.p: Forms part of the Eastern Wine and Grape Archive. (EWGA)
Related material located in collection #8132, Chisholm-Ryder mechanical grape harvester records.

U.S. and Canadian grape production data as early as 1909. 1945 Grape census. Also includes Annual Finger Lakes Grape Tour data from the 1940s, published in 1949, inludes the following vineyeards, Elvira, Granby, Beers, Fox, Kimbar (at the German prison camp), Depot, all these were owned by Widmer Wine Cellars.
Many from the Grape Belt

scopecontent.p: Includes paper on Promising New Grape Selections form the New York State Breeding Program with descriptions of many crosses. Also papers oninterstock and vigor grant proposal, heat treated riesling, Ethrel trials at Taylor vineyard, Alar, American Journal of Enology and Viticulture Guide to Authors. Also a bilbiography of works, possibly used in class Horticulture 355.
Includes, International Symposium on Cool Climate Viticulture and Enology at Wine Expo '84, NEC-9 minutes.
